name: Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition
description: Set out on a grand adventure in this turn-based, retro style, pixel-art RPG, inspired by the great titles of the 90's. Take on the roles of in-game players taking on the roles of their characters in a traditional pen and paper RPG session in the ultimate meta roleplaying experience.
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows XP or later Processor:2000 MHz Memory:512 MB RAM Graphics:640x480 minimum resolution (Direct3D/OpenGL compatible card with at least 128MB) DirectX®:9.0c Hard Drive:100 MB HD space Sound:2D sound compatible card

reviews.review_text: I admit, I miss tabletop gaming. I miss the DM trying to kill off my characters. I miss creating ridiculously out-of-the-box characters. Heck, I miss the days of popcorn, Mountain Dew, and just hanging out and rolling some dice. Those days have been gone for me quite some time ago, and yet playing a little game called Knights of Pen and Paper reminded me of those good old days.  Knights of Pen and Paper attempts to mimic tabletop gaming for an accessible audience. Players start by selecting three noobs to join the adventuring party, along with their class and starting skill. Like any tabletop RPG, as the adventuring party explores, kills baddies, and completes quests, they earn experience to level up and gain more skills. Each party member gets one skill point every time they level up and can only put points into one of four skills. While this creates simplicity for those unfamiliar with RPGs, it doesn't provide a lot of variety.  In fact, variety is what Knights of Pen and Paper struggles with throughout its twenty hour campaign. Although the backgrounds mimic an 8-bit style, there isn't much in terms of detail or design. The soundtrack loops, but it feels like there's only three tracks in the entire game. Although there's plenty of classes in the game, many of them are locked and the requirements for unlocking them appear random. The base classes — paladin, mage, cleric, etc. — while classic, are trapped with only four skills, which wouldn't be the case in tabletop gaming.  While variety isn't the game's strong suit, accessibility is. It provides a simple turn-based battle system wherein players can select between attack, skill, defend, item, and flee. This makes for an easy learning experience, but it lacks any real depth that a tabletop game has. The game is also surprisingly grindy, and while it does a great job of teaching players what to expect in encounters (usually enemies three to five levels higher than the adventuring party), it's a bit crazy how much players will have to stop and grind because it's not entirely on par with the party's level. It feels like the developers set out to make a simple RPG to give players the feel of tabletop gaming, but the combat could have benefitted from actual dice rolls on screen to indicate whether or not the player's characters succeeded or fail in their actions. However, with the grindy combat, perhaps adding dice rolls would have just made everything take longer than provide more accessibility. Still, the combat lacks depth and it needs something else to make it a more engaging process.  Dice rolling does exist within Knights of Pen and Paper, it's just not as frequent as it should be. Dice rolls occur when players travel between areas, failures leading to battles, successes leading to safety. Dice rolls occur when players are mining for grindstones or moving through dungeons. These elements are done well and are fairly straightforward, but this game would really benefit if it was implemented into all actions, especially if its goal is to mimic tabletop games. What's further disappointing is the campaign itself. While the writing is charming and hilarious, the majority of the quests are either escort missions, collecting items, slaying some bad dudes, or traveling from place to place for plot purposes. The amount of backtracking in this game is brutal and inexcusable, and even the adventuring party complains about it. It goes back to that problem of accessibility versus variety — on one hand, the campaign should be easy to learn and follow along, on the other hand there should be more to do than then the standard affair. The charm in the writing, and even its awkward translation errors, can only go so far and will likely leave veteran RPGamers wanting something more substantial.  However, Knights of Pen and Paper does succeed in its overall atmosphere. Players get the sense of gamers hanging out, bantering, and asking to pass the Mountain Dew. There is an overal sense that the Dungeon Master is out to kill the adventuring party, and the back and forth within the writing really does work well. The graphics and music, though overly simplistic, are vibrant and give the feeling that players are on an adventure and there is loot to be had. The game is also a fantastic time waster because in its lack of depth it success at being the type of mindless game where players find themselves going, 'just one more quest.' Considering all of the game's flaws, it admittedly succeeds in the one area that for some people matters most: it's actually fun.  There are some perks in Knights of Pen and Paper's PC release that differ from the original mobile version. For starters, it allows players to leave party members at the tavern, and bring a new adventurers into the party. They can roll for a new character and not feel like they have to start their entire campaign from scratch. There's also an extended campaign for those who want to explore more of what the game has to offer, and there's tons of new dungeons and loot to acquire. The main campaign can be completed in around twenty hours, with the extended campaign offering quite a bit of repaly value. There's also tons of items that can be purchased in shops that can give added bonuses to various stats, which is a nice cosmetic feature.  Knights of Pen and Paper is a sweet little throwback to the days of pen and paper gaming, but its simple approach may not be enough to entice every RPGamer. Yes, the combat is simplistic, but it's fast and easy to roll with. Sure, the story is simple, but it's cute in its presentation. Knights of Pen and Paper's imperfections are many, and yet it's completely easy to sink time into. It's straightforward in its approach and yet, despite its flaws and frustration, I kept playing. Knights of Pen and Paper will never offer gamers a deep experience, but it offers mindless gameplay that admittedly can keep you coming back for more.    Recommended

This is a very simple looking RPG on the cover but once you get into it, there is plenty of min/maxing to be done. A turn based gameplay makes fits this much more than a normal action type. I love how you can swap in 'team members' to the table once you purchase more seats at the table.  Another thing which is probably overlooked in Knights of Pen & Paper, is the dialog of the dungeon master and the players, some really humours lines came out during my playthrough and I would really recommend anyone read through them for a giggle.   The soundtracks can get fairly repetitve but what do you expect for an 8bit style game. I'm up to about twelve hours gameplay and I am still finding new things to try out.   I would 100% recommend this to any RPG/Turn based fan

Imagine playing table top D&D, and getting sucked into the world of Nintendo, where you are still playing Table top D&D, only you are playing it as an NES video game. That pretty much sums up this game in a nutshell, only you play it on the PC. It looks like an old school NES game, but incorporates the table top D&D feel, Very interesting concept. Much different than the early video game D&D adventures, this game tries to stay true to old school D&D. I thought it was a fun little game and would recommend it, because it can be picked up for next to nothing or even free and if you enjoy anything D&D related, you should at least give it a try. Get ready for a Nostalgia rush.

At first, Knights of Pen and Paper was VERY fun. I enjoyed the little jabs the GM gave, I felt like I was being challenged fairly, it felt like I was playing a fun little tabletop. I even bought the Halloween DLC because I was having such a good time with it.  But then the challenges became SO exhausting. Toward the end it feels like you're just stuck in mud and can't progress no matter how high you level up. It stopped being fun and became a chore. If you enjoy grinding this game could be for you.   Personally, not a big fan.

I expected Knights Of Pen And Paper +1 to be an old school RPG with a full story mode, but instead it's a game where you create and complete your own quests. It sounds clever as your characters are also placed behind a table and there's a guy that acts as a dungeon master, but so far I've been doing nothing but completing boring quests and grinding so I can level up my characters. *This is not the game you're looking for.* It's not the one I'm looking for, anyway.  [Rating: 64/100]

I spent a fair bit more time with this game on the mobile version. I like the conceit, and it seems like something I would enjoy, but I never really fell in love. Felt kinda grindy. Never finished it.

a great game for any D&D player or fan of the tabletop games. i had a lot of fun with this game and how accurate the game is to playing D&D it really captures the struggle, combat and hilariousness of playing D&D with ninja turtles, mario mushrooms and giant bosses not to mention the customizable options to the game such as being able to customize your fellow players at the table and swtich them out or changing the dungeon master this game has it all along with it having a 8 bit style of art and an RPG element and turn based style to the gameplay this game was really enjoyable and super fun to play i would highly recommened giving this gem of a game a chance :)

Despite no mention of it anywhere, this game contains microstransactions that will make the game easier. This means that on top earning money through game sales themselves, the game is continually monetised through the sale of more in game currency. It also suggests that the difficulty and the amount of mindless grinding required in the game to progress is geared toward frustrating you into getting out your wallet to buy progress with real world cash.  This business model is unacceptable. If I pay money for a game I expect there to be a final transaction for me to enjoy the game as is. When I'm expected to buy my progress through the game on the other hand, under no circumstances do I want to pay money up front, especially not without being notified of these transactions. I don't want to pay a fair price for a game only to find out that I will have to invest a lot more to really enjoy it.  The game itself seemed clever at times, but I soon felt forced to either grind through enemies at a boringly slow pace or fork over real cash.
I thought it was gunna be some cheapy little indie blob, but its actually pretty fun. It is what it looks like, nothing fncy graphically, combat, or any of that, but it has its own charm.

This has all the elements of a biting, creative satire, with a setup where you pick from stereotypes of PNP players, embark on lampshadedly obvious quests and can buy nachos and soda as powerups.  Then it turns out they're completely serious.  Then you uninstall the game.
A game where you play as people playing a game.

If you're a GFX junkie, then this game certainly is not for you. Graphics and mucis are all 8bit and at first glance the game itself seems to be written in some old version of BASIC on a Comodore 64 (which is actually quite possible :D). But underneat that layer of all that 8bit gloss there's an extremely fun game!  This game is full of humor and all standard old-school pen-n-paper RPG clichés that you have probably done when you actually played those pen-n-paper games with friends. Sadly though, that DM kinda sucks. If I had him for a DM in my pen-n-paper sessions, we'd have long discussions about NPC naming, story telling and such. But I think this is most likely yet an other prank from the developers :p  I picked it up for €2,50 on the sale today, but if I knew this game was so much fun, I would have bought it earlier and have paid the €10 as well. It's really worth it, so much fun this game gives me!

This game pulls off imitating the tabletop experience well for good and for ill.  THINGS THS IS GAME DOES LIKE TABLETOP GAMING: ~Travel is quick because travel is boring. ~Travel is still something that you have to do too much. ~The NPCs that stand out remain well in your memory ~The NPCs that don't are all exactly the same re-skinned NPC, other than MAYBE half a dozen they are all boring ~The jokes remind me of the same type of self-referencial humor as expereinced with your first highschool GM ~The jokes still suck. ~The early game is a desperate struggle against keeping the squishies alive long enough for them to unleash the hurt on the enemies. ~The late game every fight is waiting on the wizard or equivilant to denign to cast the right spell after the rest of the party spend the whole combat setting it up. ~Enemies actually have some flavor to them that is easily apparent. ~Enemies are universially made tougher by merit of adding hitpoints and raw damage rather than tricks or tactics.  I wish the game had more elements of randomness, like miss chances based ona rolled die in combat rather than it only being effected on the map.  I'm marking this as a RECOMMEND, but only buy it if you really like old school RPGs and/or tabletop gaming

Heh.  -_-  Okay, so: do you A.) Like Dungeons and Dragons-style adventuring games? B.) Like playing actual D&D style games, on pen and paper? C.) Would like to try a simulator of the two?  This is that game.   Will you like it? That's debatable.  I bought this game when it was a daily deal because I like pen and paper D&D-style games. Note that I had received all of the boosts from the digital deluxe version.  The retro-style graphics are a nice aesthetic, and there is quite a bit of variety with the creatures you will encounter in the game.  So the game plays with you as the DM (dungeon master) overseeing a game of D20 Knights of Pen and Paper. You have seats that can sit how ever many characters you would like to use, but the last few seats require you to pay the in-game currency. You can keep grinding to afford the seats in the future.  For each seat, you can sit a type of character (ex: hipster, grandma) and assign them a specific class (ex: barbarian, bard). This offers a seemingly wide range of party configurations.  The difficulty is completely self-driven, as you are both the DM and the players. That being said, you may have an 'objective' to kill 5 orcs - you can choose to fight them 1-at-a-time, or all at once, or whatever configuration you prefer. The entirety of the game involves A LOT of grinding, and this is even considering the boosts you may have gotten from the deluxe edition.   I love D20 games, but this game can become repetitive extremely quickly. If there was a multiplayer cooperative functionality, it might have saved it a bit, however, there isn't one.  There is A LOT of variety for you to upgrade - you can change everything from the type of table you're playing on (each type provides different bonuses) to the type of door in the room to the DM. All of this can help shape your overall party into a specfic area, like tanky high HP characters, or high MP, magic-relying casters.  I paid ~$5 US for the deluxe edition, and I think even then you may want to hold off and wait for it to be cheaper, if you are interested in trying the game.
Enjoyable , little time waster

Pros: The game is kind of humorous. The backgrounds look nice. They removed microtransactions  Cons: The gameplay lacks any depth. The game is super grindy. The game is REALLY resource intensive for what it is. (It uses 14% to 17% of my CPU just idling at the title screen.) Text is recycled far too often. The music isn't bad, but it is way too short. So in a given fight it probably loops 5 or 6 times. Alternate save files don't have independant gold, room items, characters, or classes; however, the blacksmith doesn't carry over. (The whole idea of all that being persistent is just stupid as it was physically impossible to get the game over achievement unless I deleted my save file.) More of a nitpick, but the developers made themselves the best characters in the game. (That's a bit too narassistic, in my opinion, and since they have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ one-liners it ruins most of the fun of the game.)   Overall: I got the game in a sale because it looked like it would fun to play. Little did I know I would just make a party full of physical attackers, leave the twister floor mat on, and just run this in the background while I played other games. The game got a bit of a chuckle from me when I first played it, but as the game dragged on it just got more monotonous due to there being no real growth in the game. Everything in the game scales linearly, including mana costs, so it's more about playing keep up with how much health the enemies in later areas have as opposed to actually feeling strong.

15+ hours of gameplay and progress gone because an untested patch by the devs wiped all savegames. The game itself is nice, the fact of losing your savegame to their incompetency however is NOT. I am certainly not playing it from the beginning again and will scratch my plans to buy the sequel. Thanks but no thanks.

This game is somehow entertaining even though devs use microtransactions model in paid ($10 or so!) game. Yeah, you can buy in-game coins for real money! This fact just pisses me off.  Personally I don't recommend to buy this game.  4/10
Tons of content, great choice of characters and a battle system that isn't taxing.

A great game to get hours out of.

Enjoyed it for almost two hours, before I found out you could pay some extra to get more coins. Intant-F4. No indie-game like this one is worth more than retail price. Would not recommend.

If you've ever been a fan of table-top fantasy games, you need to buy this ASAP.  It has a lot of other aspects that would certainly appeal to a lot of other people, but that's what drew me in, and that's what's going to keep me playing. If you want another opinion, read another review.  10/10 this game is what it says it is, does what it says it does, and does not disappoint.
OMG, as an avid tabletop and RPG player, I was laughing my ♥♥♥ off within the first 5 min of this game. Highly recommend getting the deluxe edition of the game.

This game is dope as hell. I didn't know what to expect of it, but it looked cute, so I tried it. It's addictive, it's witty, and it's just good ol turn-based funtimes. I think it's an awesome way to waste your time :D
simple, fun, and good game

It's a charming concept that loses its charm fairly quickly. The humor gets old, and the combat system gets boring and repetitive. The story is pretty bland and its execution is poor, drowned in the midst of required jobber battles that the game throws at you in a mockery of typical poor DMing style. It's got the American Nightmare problem in which it acknowledges why what it's parodying is lame, but doesn't actually do anything to fix it. Something that's ironically bad is still, unfortunately, bad.  In all, it feels like a quirky, above-average quickie mobile game that sells itself as an engaging RPG.  If you like that sort of thing, then get it when it's on sale. It's not worth $10.

Knights of Pen and Paper +1 Edition is a strange little game that takes the fourth wall and breaks it. It doesn't just take a sledgehammer to it or anything, it demolishes that wall and lets you view a weird (but amusing) hybrid of a pen-and-paper RPG with the characters as well.  Visually the game manages to hold it's unique touch, even on the PC platform. Music also does fairly well at making itself memorable in terms of it's melody but to some it could get extremely repetitive over time.  While this game does have an in-game-store with which you can buy 'gold' (the game's currency for getting buffs and permanent benefits, but the gold is just as easily earned by playing making the in-game-store a bit useless except to those who are extremely impatient.  The game can be a great time waster for people wanting to poke a little fun at the D&D genre and has taken a good number of hours from me. Without the timed waits that the mobile version has, this is a much better build that just lets you play without interference.
Overall, a pretty fun game, but a very lazy port. Under Linux, all 'Deluxe' features are missing (if that's the version you bought) and in both Linux and Windows, achievements are spotty at best.

I feel torn about this game. At first it was interesting in the simplicity and style, yet as the game progresses it feel immensely tedious. There will be quests where you are required to go from one location to another and have to fight at each step along the way, sometimes up to five or six battles. Then once you arrive the quest is to slay a number of monsters repeatedly. The endgame seems almost unfair, requiring a lot of grinding unless you spend a lot of time exploring sidequests. Based on the price, I think the game has a niche in the category of game where you advance through it periodically while taking a break from other games. Could improvements be made? Absolutely, but for an indie title with some creative 4th wall shattering, it serves it's place decently.
Turn based JRPG uninteresting on every level -- tactics, writing, etc.. I'm ashamed to have played this grindy bore to the end.

I love this game! I bought it after the 'no more microtransactions' update, so I haven't had any issues with paying to win. Even though it is a very XP grinding game, for some reason I enjoy doing the monotonous quests and collecting items over and over. Very fun, lots of great classes and characters.   If you're into turn-based, RPG, XP grinding games, buy this game!   4.5/5

First game I've ever bought on Steam where I've not actually gotten what I paid for. Sure sometimes a game will have bugs, and sometimes there may be un-noticed system requirements/limitations which are my fault for missing. But here, it's not even the right product. Advertised as win/mac/linux, but buying the deluxe version, none of that extra content shows up for linux. No response from the publisher/devs on their own steam forum linux-specific discussion. First time I've ever felt truly cheated on Steam.   Edit: Dec 12th, 2014 WIth the latest update, it seems that at long last 2 1/2 months later, the Deluxe Version finally works under linux. Of course they've still been selling for Linux this whole time instead of taking that off until it was fixed. What miniscule communication there has been in that time was all of poor quality and incorrect. Moreover this actual fix wasn't even described or announced. Still cannot recommend.

What the helll, this shouldn't have a 'Very Positive' overall review, what is wrong with these people. Don't get me wrong, i think its actually a great mobile game, but for a steam PC game, its ridiculous, it shouldn't be here. Cute game, but needlessly difficult.   My game functionally ended when enough of my party died that I couldn't reliably fight and didn't have enough cash to resurrect anyone. Could I have farmed for the money in low level fights? Yes. Was that prospect enjoyable? Not in the least.  I do enjoy that while the game has some pretty standard stereotypes of gamers, it also embraces women, jocks, and businessmen, amongst others, at the table.   All the geek culture shout-outs were amusing.  Still, any game I can't finish isn't a game I'm going to recommend.
Its one of the best games that I have ever played.
simple, has a lot o funny refrenmces and i simply love it.

A lite-D&D game with prebuilt classes and occasional funny text, the game stays a fun and balanced play until the +1 content. At this point the story improves, but the need to grind is introduced in large amounts. A good 20~30 hrs of content. 8/10

Boring.  Knights of Pen & Paper is long, dull, grindy and most of all it is boring. It starts out novel enough. You are playing a game about a bunch of gamers playing D&D A few obvious jokes and references and things start out pretty well. The sound, music, graphics, they all lend themselves pretty well.  But the grind, jeez! This is a single player game! Who thought that... Converted mobile app with a cash shop in the mobile version? Ooooooooooooooooh  I don't need to say much more really. As far as converted mobile games go its actually really well ported. But the play time is so artifically padded that you probably will not complete the game.  A sequel has been announced and I hope and pray it addresses the flaws this game has or even just does away with the excessive grinding for the inevitable PC port.  I know some smartass will reply that this is an RPG and you are supposed to grind but this isn't 1997 anymore. Games like Bravely Default, like Magic Fantasy Battle 4, have come along and said 'listen, there is grinding but we streamlined it or we made it  fun .'  I stopped caring about the storyline the 8th time I was told to backtrack for excuse reasons. I especially stopped caring when my Lv32 Barbarian, with maxed equipment, wearing 4 +9attack items, still can't one shot a friggen spider!  I especially was agitated that a newer version of this game was released that I can't simply upgrade too, or even buy apprently since steam says 'you already own that game' when clearly I don't.   Flaws aside the game is enjoyable in short bursts which is fitting given its mobile phone roots. It was ported to the PC and no real effort was made to make it a more PC friendly game. Instead its dull, repetitive and boring. Also the achievement, beat in 365 (game)days, is unachievable it seems. That's always nice for the achievement hunters.

If you like turn-based fantasy combat and have nostalgia for tabletop RPGs, this just might be the game for you!  Gameplay can be a bit repetitive, so it's not really a game you can sit and play for six hours, but but half an hour here, two hours there? It's lovely! And there are some interesting story turns I've encountered so far.  Mostly I love it because it's not too serious, not too involved, perfect for a short gaming session, and has a great sense of humor. Perfect for when I've got a bit of time to kill. Tough battles can also require some careful thought or you'll find your party dead! And it's great how you can adjust the battles yourself, decide how tough it'll be, and challenge yourself as much as you like. Lot of customization in the gaming experience.  Plus, so many things to buy in the shops and so many items to find!  Seriously, I love the game.

An old-school roleplay type game that can suck you in to a magical world where pizza guys can make a meteor hit people. Also, in a world where blacksmiths everywhere have over 500 grindstones sitting in their shop for now apparent reason!  :D
This game is a very hidden game but I believe that given the effort it can be shown to a lot more people. Overall, a very addictive but very fun game.
This is one of the rare gems of RPG. I love it very very much, the puns, the setting, the retro pixel graphic. It is a must buy for all the lovers of proper RPG

I love this game, it's witty, can be fun if you enjoy the grind, is fun once you've bought enough boosting items. This game has a lot of 80's kid focused humor.  It's loaded with great nostalgia/references and beautifully done pixel art, the sound is great though you will likely turn the music off after 3-5 hours of playing.  You can have several parties going at once and share earned gold across parties which can make for interesting progression styles. There are permenant upgrades to your table and the room you're playing from that really change the way the game is played and I felt that was a very nice touch.  The DEV team was bought out so there's no real support for the game anymore, it has some odd bugs in it still and can occasionally break if you do some things too quickly.  Overall 100%ing this game was fun and a steady challenge it took me just under 30 hours.  I have a difficult time recommending this game though since it's not really something that just anyone can pick up and play. This game can be frustratingly difficult at times. Especially if your party composition is unable to overcome an obstacle, you may have to start a new game to support your main party.  But I've decided to recommend it due to the 8bit charm it has throughout the game which is really entertaining.

A simple game that carefully balances some of the best and irreplacable facets of gaming both modern and retro. This game offers a really nice blend of modern humour and references in the form of turn-based Retro Pixel-art, all of which is set in a world set inside a game of dungeons and dragons-or-some-similar-RPG. If you have played DnD you'll get a couple of references that might tickle you greatly but its not a pre-requisite to have fun with this little gem.   Great bang for your buck, good looking, nice sounding and entertaining. But I wont tell you anymore incase I ruin the magical adventure :D
Brings back old memories. Having fun playing this.

I love this game. Everything about it has an old-school feel that blends tabletop RPGs with NES graphics. There is a lot of grinding in this game, but that's what RPGs are about. You choose your initial characters from an assortment of people who each have their own unique bonuses, then pick a class for them based on those bonuses and what you want in your party.   If you make challenging enough fights, they require a bit of strategy. My paladin typically casts a shield to reduce damage by 50%, then increases his threat to draw attention, while my rogue stuns people for 3 turns (thanks to items I have that extend the time by 2 turns). My mage will either AoE the entire group or fireball for a burning DoT. My cleric has a powerful single heal, decent group heal, an offensive move called smite, and a debuff on 3 enemy's attack strength. My newest addition, the berserker, goes berserk (I can't choose his targets but he gains extra damage and regen) and has passives/equipment that boost his crit rate above 30% while also allowing him to heal for 63% of his total damage. And those are just my 5 classes, there's quite a few more to unlock as you play.  The grinding part comes in two forms. You'll find yourself moving back and forth to caves often to get grindstones to upgrade your blacksmith. You'll also want to fight a lot, and grind quests to earn gold. Gold can be spent buying yourself some equipment at the blacksmith, or on a whole bunch of upgrades to the room you play in, the table you play on, etc. Purchases made will give your party bonuses, such as higher RNG die rolls, more gold/exp, boosted stats, regen, etc.  There's always something to do in this game. It can be tedious at times, but the humor of the game, including comments from the game master and party members help to ease this. Overall, I think it would be a worthy addition to anyone's library who is a fan of old school RPGs.

Hard to recommend, but recommending nonetheless. Why? It's just full of charm, funny little cultural references and has a pretty good amount of content. However combat gets very boring as each class has 4 abilities, one of which is just a passive for 80-90% of the classes. So you largely spam the same 1-2 abilities, with the rare use (sometimes once a fight later on) of a 3rd ability, and sometimes a basic attack.  Other gripe is upgrading items at the blacksmith. Farming grindstones takes forever after the 1st or 2nd upgrade for him. However if you want upgrades without spending ALL of your gold, you need to gather dozens of these at a time for a 5-10% increase in chance of succesfully forging an item. Don't even bother trying unless you're at about 60% success, because you can waste almost all your gold upgrading one or two items. It's a shame because this could have been a really fun and important mechanic, but feels really forced. The only way to get grindstones is travel to caves, and hopefully roll a high enough number for each ore vein present, or spend 25 G a piece. As I said though this can take ALOT of grindstones and buying that amount can really add up in early-midgame as gold generally isnt earned fast. Battles (depending on bonuses of items you have and what you are fighting) generally drop 1-20 gold.  The blacksmith, repetive fighting and slow accumlation of gold are painfully dull or even annoying. However, the concept, dialogue, references, simplicity and music keep it entertaining enough to play for 20 or so minutes at a time.

Look... if you have this game, was most likely part of a bundle. But I wouldn't have bought it otherwise. The game was supposed to be retro and amusing but turned into a horrible grind. A really *grindy* grind. It was cute for a while but then quickly got annoying... and the pop-culture references have been done to death.  The quests often were 'Kill 7 of X then come back' or 'Collect 7-12 drops from Y then come back' and there were a few examples where you had do it that 4 times in a row. You have to pay gold to walk between locations, so it feels like you're questing on a Monopoly board; 'Go south 2, kill 7, come back' or 'Escort 5 spaces East, get attacked every step, come back' while you are paying each way. Dumb.  The little dungeon system... is annoying. You can't rest or run away from a fight or it boots you out and you have to do the whole dungeon again. You have to wander around to find the key for the boss fight, taking damage from fights or traps 75% of the time. Who does that? Who is going to spend time to do 10-50 of those for the achievement? Pass. Just pass.

Between Steam and the Android version, I've surely logged 40 or 50 hours on this game. It's great fun, and the game-within-a-game structure makes for some funny moments in the main quest. While the gameplay can get a little stale after you've maxed everyone out (not hard to do), it's still a fun diversion from time to time. I can wholeheartedly recommend KoP&P, but at the same time ... it's game that's also a tremendous missed opportunity for something greater.  My big complaint about the game is the lack of additional content. The one DLC, 'Haunted Fall,' is a mere sliver of addtional content, and hardly worth the price. This is the kind of game that SCREAMS for a rich set of adds ons and expansions, particularly for high-level gameplay. After two years, however, we have one lackluster, overpriced expansion that would have been a free upgrade from most other publishers.  If it had Steam Workshop support, it could easily become one of the best pick-up-and-play RPG games out there. But, again, we have nothing like that. Just a great core game and some tantatlizingly untapped potential.  That said, at $10 it's a touch on the pricey side. I picked my copy up on sale for perhaps $5, and when the DLC was maybe $3. It's a great deal at $8, but I'm not sure I'd feel the same way at $20 for the Deluxier version. If you can get it on steep sale, you won't regret it. Otherwise, stick to the much cheaper mobile version,

As a disclaimer, I got this game with the humble bundle. At first I thought this game looked interesting. Jokes baout tabletop RPGs? Yes! Good pixelart? Oh my yes! Turn based combat? Eh, not my favourite, but there's worse.  When I started playing the game was allright. The story wasn't nearly as good as I thought it was going to be, but the gameplay wasn't as bad as I thought, so that kept me going. The difficulty of the game kept going upwards, which is understandable. I did enjoy it. For a while. Then I hit a pay wall. Yes, this game has in-app-purchases for gold, which the whole game revolves around; with enough gold you could pretty much beat the whole game while using a first level character. The whole game is constructed around selling this gold, at least seemingly; although the grind times were long at some points, I didn't mind since games like these always have long grind times. However when I spent a very long time grinding for a single fight, I realized that the game is geared toward trying to get you to buy gold.  Good game. Bad business model. Not worth 10 dollar. I'd say buy it for one or two if the concept interests you, and as always, veer as far away from making in-app-purchases in a game you already paid for as possible.

Knights of Pen and Paper is a throwback to old school table top rpg's. At least it presents it self that way. You have a dungeon master that sits at a table along with your party. Knights of Pen and Paper is charming. That's how people tend to describe it. I'd consider it a scripted digital version of Dungeons & Dragons. It even has some of the old tongue-in-cheek humor present in the old sessions my friends and I used to play late into the night. Overall, it's a very fun, very tedious, very strategic, and, above all, simply charming.  I can't say I cared much for the grind. There is a fair bit of that in this game, with the quests all following the same basic structure. Go here, kill this, escort this person. What keeps this game alive is the sly humor and nods to other cultural institutions (Steam Island and Nabe Gewell among them). Truthfully, its replay value is pretty low. When I realized I had to play two campaigns for the achievements, I was thoroughly disappointed. The first time though, I laughed, I cried, I couldn't put it down. When it came time to play it agian, I literally couldn't be bothered to.  On balance, this game receieves a positive recommendation for me. Even though it's a bit tedious to get all the achievements (so. much. gold. grinding.), I think that it's a fun casual game for non-completionists. If you're after all the achievements, it won't be too hard. You'll get them. A thousand hours and an endless grind later.
